title: 109_hr4867
content:
The Puerto Rico Democracy Act of 2006 establishes a federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including an initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. It also addresses applicable laws, requirements, and the availability of funds for the self-determination process. The Congress acknowledges past presidential actions regarding Puerto Rico's political status, including the establishment of a task force to identify options for the territory's future status. President George W. Bush amended the executive order to require regular reports on progress. President George W. Bush's Executive Order 13183, amended in 2003, mandated regular reports by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status. In 2005, the Task Force recommended a federally sanctioned plebiscite for Puerto Ricans to choose between remaining a territory or pursuing a permanent nonterritorial status. Congress should provide for a subsequent plebiscite in Puerto Rico to choose between two permanent nonterritorial status options. If the people elect to remain a US territory, periodic plebiscites should occur to keep Congress informed of their wishes. Federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite in Puerto Rico to choose between continuing the existing territorial status or pursuing a path towards a nonterritorial status. If the majority favors the current status, additional plebiscites will be held every 8 years. If a majority vote in a plebiscite favors the existing territorial status, the Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will hold additional plebiscites every 8 years. If a majority votes for permanent nonterritorial status, a plebiscite will be conducted with options for statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. The ballot options for Puerto Rico's status include becoming a sovereign nation or remaining in free association with the United States. A plebiscite will be held within 2 years if a majority vote favors permanent nonterritorial status. SEC. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS. SEC. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS.

(a) Applicable Laws.--Federal laws applicable to the election of the Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico also apply to any plebiscite under this Act. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over legal claims. Puerto Rico State Elections Commission issues rules. Eligible voters include those under Puerto Rico electoral laws and U.S. citizens born in Puerto Rico. Persons eligible to vote in Puerto Rico plebiscites include all US citizens born in Puerto Rico who meet the State Elections Commission requirements. They can request an absentee ballot. The Commission certifies plebiscite results to the President and Congress. After the second plebiscite, a report is submitted to Congress by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status will submit a report to Congress detailing measures to implement the chosen nonterritorial status option in the plebiscite. The report will be prepared in consultation with key Puerto Rican officials. During the period from October 1, 2006, until all required plebiscites are completed, the Secretary of the Treasury can allocate up to $5,000,000 from funds provided to Puerto Rico for plebiscite expenses, including voter education materials approved by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status.
